title: We can compile the above file using this command:

inline_content.Text: We can compile the above file using this command:

title: This produces a file called “HelloWorld.class”, which we can then run as follows:

inline_content.Text: This produces a file called “HelloWorld.class”, which we can then run as follows:

title: The key points to note from this example are:

inline_content.Text: The key points to note from this example are:

title: The source filename “HelloWorld.java” must match the class name in the source file … which is
HelloWorld
c
. If they don’t match, you will get a compilation error.

inline_content.Text: The source filename “HelloWorld.java” must match the class name in the source file … which is
HelloWorld
. If they don’t match, you will get a compilation error.

title: The bytecode filename “HelloWorld.class” corresponds to the classname. If you were to rename the “HelloWorld.class”, you would get an error when your tried to run it.

inline_content.Text: The bytecode filename “HelloWorld.class” corresponds to the classname. If you were to rename the “HelloWorld.class”, you would get an error when your tried to run it.

title: When running a Java application using
java
c
, you supply the classname NOT the bytecode filename.

inline_content.Text: When running a Java application using
java
, you supply the classname NOT the bytecode filename.
Example with packages

title: Most practical Java code uses packages to organize the namespace for classes and reduce the risk of accidental class name collision.

inline_content.Text: Most practical Java code uses packages to organize the namespace for classes and reduce the risk of accidental class name collision.

title: If we wanted to declare the
HelloWorld
c
class in a package call
com.example
c
, the “HelloWorld.java” would contain the following Java source:

inline_content.Text: If we wanted to declare the
HelloWorld
class in a package call
com.example
, the “HelloWorld.java” would contain the following Java source:

title: This source code file needs to stored in a directory tree whose structure corresponds to the package naming.

inline_content.Text: This source code file needs to stored in a directory tree whose structure corresponds to the package naming.

title: We can compile the above file using this command:

inline_content.Text: We can compile the above file using this command:

title: This produces a file called “com/example/HelloWorld.class”; i.e. after compilation, the file structure should look like this:

inline_content.Text: This produces a file called “com/example/HelloWorld.class”; i.e. after compilation, the file structure should look like this:

title: We can then run the application as follows:

inline_content.Text: We can then run the application as follows:

title: Additional points to note from this example are:

inline_content.Text: Additional points to note from this example are:

title: The directory structure must match the package name structure.

inline_content.Text: The directory structure must match the package name structure.

title: When you run the class, the full class name must be supplied; i.e. “com.example.HelloWorld” not “HelloWorld”.

inline_content.Text: When you run the class, the full class name must be supplied; i.e. “com.example.HelloWorld” not “HelloWorld”.

title: You don’t have to compile and run Java code out of the current directory. We are just doing it here for illustration.

inline_content.Text: You don’t have to compile and run Java code out of the current directory. We are just doing it here for illustration.

title: Compiling multiple files at once with ‘javac’.

inline_content.Text: Compiling multiple files at once with ‘javac’.

title: If your application consists of multiple source code files (and most do!) you can compile them one at a time. Alternatively, you can compile multiple files at the same time by listing the pathnames:

inline_content.Text: If your application consists of multiple source code files (and most do!) you can compile them one at a time. Alternatively, you can compile multiple files at the same time by listing the pathnames:

title: or using your command shell’s filename wildcard functionality ….

inline_content.Text: or using your command shell’s filename wildcard functionality ….

title:
$ javac *.java
$ javac com/example/*.java
$ javac */**/*.java #Only works on Zsh or with globstar enabled on your shell

content_resolved.code:
$ javac *.java
$ javac com/example/*.java
$ javac */**/*.java #Only works on Zsh or with globstar enabled on your shell

title: This will compile all Java source files in the current directory, in the “com/example” directory, and recursively in child directories respectively. A third alternative is to supply a list of source filenames (and compiler options) as a file. For example:

inline_content.Text: This will compile all Java source files in the current directory, in the “com/example” directory, and recursively in child directories respectively. A third alternative is to supply a list of source filenames (and compiler options) as a file. For example:

sourcefiles
file contains:

title: Note: compiling code like this is appropriate for small one-person projects, and for once-off programs. Beyond that, it is advisable to select and use a Java build tool. Alternatively, most programmers use a Java IDE (e.g.
NetBeans
a
https://netbeans.org/
eclipse
a
https://eclipse.org/
IntelliJ IDEA
a
https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/
) which offers an embedded compiler and incremental building of “projects”.

inline_content.Text: Note: compiling code like this is appropriate for small one-person projects, and for once-off programs. Beyond that, it is advisable to select and use a Java build tool. Alternatively, most programmers use a Java IDE (e.g.
NetBeans
eclipse
IntelliJ IDEA
) which offers an embedded compiler and incremental building of “projects”.
Commonly used ‘javac’ options

title: Here are a few options for the
javac
c
command that are likely to be useful to you

inline_content.Text: Here are a few options for the
javac
command that are likely to be useful to you

title: The
-d
c
option sets a destination directory for writing the “.class” files.

inline_content.Text: The
-d
option sets a destination directory for writing the “.class” files.

title: The
-sourcepath
c
option sets a source code search path.

inline_content.Text: The
-sourcepath
option sets a source code search path.

title: The
-cp
c
or
-classpath
c

option sets the search path for finding external and previously compiled classes. For more information on the classpath and how to specify it, refer to the http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/java/3720/classpath Topic.

inline_content.Text: The
-cp
or
-classpath

option sets the search path for finding external and previously compiled classes. For more information on the classpath and how to specify it, refer to the http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/java/3720/classpath Topic.

title: The
-version
c
option prints the compiler’s version information.

inline_content.Text: The
-version
option prints the compiler’s version information.

title: A more complete list of compiler options will be described in a separate example.

inline_content.Text: A more complete list of compiler options will be described in a separate example.
References
The definitive reference for the
javac
command is the
Oracle manual page for
javac
